title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #92** asks about equidistant points in point sets.

**Setup**: For a set A of n points, f(n) is the maximum k such that every point in A has at least k other points equidistant from it.

**Questions**: Is f(n) ≤ n^{o(1)}? Or even f(n) < n^{c/log log n}?

**Status**: OPEN

**Prize**: $500
mathContext: This is a 'stronger form' of the unit distance problem (#90). The lattice gives f(n) > n^{c/log log n}, while JJMT (2024) proved f(n) ≪ n^{4/11}.

title: Equidistance in Point Sets
content:
For each point x in a set A, we consider how many other points lie on circles centered at x.

The function f(n) asks: what's the best equidistance guarantee we can achieve for ALL points simultaneously?

This is harder than just finding one point with many equidistant neighbors.
mathContext: A point x has k equidistant neighbors if there's a distance d such that exactly k other points are at distance d from x.

title: Maximum Equidistant Points
content:
**maxEquidistantPoints x A** counts the largest number of points in A at the same distance from x.

We compute this by:
1. Erasing x from A
2. Grouping remaining points by distance to x
3. Taking the maximum group size
mathContext: Formally: for each distance d, count |{p ∈ A : dist(x,p) = d}|, then take the supremum.

title: k-Equidistant Property
content:
**hasEquidistantProperty k A** says every point x ∈ A has at least k other points equidistant from x.

This is a UNIVERSAL property: it must hold for ALL points in A, not just one.

f(n) is the maximum k achievable by some n-point set.
mathContext: Formally: A.Nonempty ∧ ∀ x ∈ A, k ≤ maxEquidistantPoints x A

title: The Function f(n)
content:
**f n** is the supremum of achievable k values for n-point sets.

This is THE function Erdős asked about: how fast does it grow?
mathContext: Defined as sSup {k | ∃ A with |A| = n and hasEquidistantProperty k A}.

title: Weak Conjecture (OPEN)
content:
**WeakConjecture** asks: Is f(n) ≤ n^{o(1)}?

This means for ANY ε > 0, f(n) ≤ n^ε eventually.

Equivalently: f(n) grows slower than any positive power of n.
mathContext: Formally: ∀ ε > 0, ∀ᶠ n in atTop, f(n) ≤ n^ε

title: Strong Conjecture (OPEN)
content:
**StrongConjecture** asks: Is f(n) < n^{c/log log n} for some c > 0?

This is more precise than the weak conjecture. It would match the lattice lower bound up to the constant.
mathContext: The exponent c/log log n → 0 very slowly. For n = 10^10, log log n ≈ 3.4.

title: JJMT Bound (2024)
content:
**jjmtBound** states: f(n) ≪ n^{4/11} ≈ n^{0.364}.

This is the best known upper bound, from Janzer, Janzer, Methuku, and Tardos (2024) using circle-point incidence bounds.

**Why an axiom?** The proof uses sophisticated incidence geometry.
mathContext: 4/11 ≈ 0.364 is still far from o(1), but improves on the earlier 2/5 = 0.4 bound.

title: Lattice Lower Bound
content:
**latticeLowerBound** states: f(n) > n^{c/log log n} for some c > 0.

The √n × √n integer lattice achieves this. Points at distance √(a² + b²) for integers a, b have high multiplicity.

This is why the strong conjecture uses n^{c/log log n} as the target.
mathContext: The lattice's equidistance structure comes from representing integers as sums of two squares.

title: Small Values (Fishburn)
content:
Fishburn computed:
- **f(6) = 3**: 6 is the smallest n with f(n) = 3
- **f(8) = 4**: 8 is the smallest n with f(n) = 4

He also suggested that lattice points may not be optimal for small n.
mathContext: These computations help understand the behavior of f(n) for small values before asymptotics dominate.
